description:
Eimeria falciformis is a species of protozoan parasite that belongs to the phylum Apicomplexa. It is an obligate intracellular parasite that primarily infects the intestinal epithelial cells of its host, which can be various species of rodents, particularly mice.

The life cycle of Eimeria falciformis involves both asexual (schizogony) and sexual (gametogony) stages. The infective stage, known as the oocyst, is shed in the feces of the infected host. Once ingested, the oocyst undergoes excystation, releasing sporozoites that invade the intestinal epithelial cells. Within these cells, the parasite undergoes multiple rounds of asexual replication, producing merozoites that can infect additional host cells.

The sexual stage of the life cycle occurs when some of the merozoites differentiate into male and female gametes, which then fuse to form a zygote. The zygote develops into an oocyst, which is then released from the host's body, completing the cycle.

Eimeria falciformis is an important model organism for the study of host-parasite interactions, immune responses, and the development of potential therapeutic interventions against coccidiosis, a disease caused by various Eimeria species in livestock and companion animals.
